lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can practise pronouncing words with the “ay” and “oy” sounds accurately.
supportStrategies: (Phonics) Say: “boy, toy, play, stay.” Students repeat, circle the sound pattern (-ay / -oy), and sort words on the board.
stretchStrategies: Students create a short “Fruit Fact Card” about one fruit. They must include a fact (where it grows), a colour word, and at least one “-ay” or “-oy” word. Share with a partner.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can read a short text about interesting fruits and find key details such as descriptions and where they grow.
supportStrategies: (Reading) Students read in pairs and highlight words describing fruit. Then answer: “Where do watermelons grow?” or “Which fruit is purple?”
stretchStrategies: Students create a short “Fruit Fact Card” about one fruit. They must include a fact (where it grows), a colour word, and at least one “-ay” or “-oy” word. Share with a partner.

lessonOutcomes.outcome: Students can learn interesting facts about how different fruits grow in different parts of the world.
supportStrategies: (Social Studies) Show images of fruit farms. Ask: “Where do these grow?” Students match fruits to countries using a map or labelled visuals.

items: Food in syllabi typically Western-centric: banh mi >> bread
Hai con chó >> two dog [two dogs]. Not only the form, but the pronunciation is tough here, as it changes depending on the final sound of the noun [s,z,iz]

Unstressed vowels do not really exist in Vietnamese, so these need extra practice. Make sure the final vowel of computer is a light schwa, not a heavy com-pu-TER. Same with the final vowel of banana. Or the second syllable of elephant. And so on.

In Vietnamese, final consonants are 'held in' – you don't actually hear them released. But in English, the final consonant of cat, top, rock, and so on are released with a puff of air. Make sure you are aware of this difference.
Do not exist in standard Vietnamese, written or spoken. The hardest part for YLs is learning to pronounce them naturally: there's a dog rather than there is a dog.
